text:
When installing the RPM, it changes the permissions of /usr/share/java/ such
that non-root users are unable to read the files within:

Here's a console log of the behavior and steps to reproduce:

[root@xxxxx /root]# ls -ld /usr/share/java/
drwxr-xr-x    2 root     root         1024 Feb 10 10:03 /usr/share/java/
[root@xxxxx /root]# rpm -i regexp-1.2-2.noarch.rpm 
[root@xxxxx /root]# ls -ld /usr/share/java/
drw-r--r--    2 root     root         1024 Feb 10 10:05 /usr/share/java/
[root@xxxxx /root]#
creator: dijit@postmark.net
dijit@postmark.net
text:
I suppose I should have stated expected results along with my actual results:
  after rpm -i, /usr/share/java should have the same permissions as before (if
it exists) and if it doesn't, the permissions should match whatever permission
other installers (the JDK installers in particular) use.

It was a bad RPM, which is no more on rpms dir
